Introduction
My research explores the evolution of plant diversity and the interaction between people and plants with a particular focus on medicinal and other useful or charismatic plants. I combine genomic data of populations and phylogenetic lineages, with analysis of important environmental or useful traits and biocultural approaches to support sustainable use and conservation.

VII International Rubiaceae and Gentianales Conference
Archived project
The Natural History Museum of Denmark invites you to Copenhagen to participate in the Seventh International Rubiaceae and Gentianales Conference that will be held from 11 to 14 September 2017. Please check the website for the latest information: http://snm.ku.dk/english/research/conferences/vii-rubiaceae-gentianales/
View
  • 5 Updates
Marie Skłodowska-Curie IF: SYMBIOSIS
Archived project
Virtually all plants interact with endophytic microorganisms that inhabit various plant organs. Although these interactions can be beneficial, neutral, or detrimental to the host and may play a larger role in host fitness and survival, the long-term effects of endosymbiosis on diversification patterns are largely unknown. Bacterial leaf symbiosis is a special type of plant-bacteria interaction where endophytes are found in the aboveground plant parts. The phenomenon is most frequently observed in the Rubiaceae family, where hundreds of species have been reported to harbour endophytic bacteria in their leaves. In this project, the long-term effect on the evolution of the Rubiaceae host plants are studied through a unique combination of plant diversity, endophytes, ecology, and time. The key scientific objective is to test whether bacterial leaf symbiosis acts as a driver for speciation. This knowledge will provide a better understanding of the impact of long-term endosymbiosis on plant diversification processes.
View
